title: Erdős #601: Infinite Paths and Independent Sets in Ordinal Graphs
description: For which limit ordinals α must every graph on α have infinite path OR independent set of order type α? Known for α < ω₁^{ω+2}. Prize: $500.

meta.author: Paul Erdős, András Hajnal, Eric Milner, Jean Larson
originalContributions: Definition of OrdinalGraph type for graphs on ordinal vertex sets
Formalization of PropertyP for ordinal graphs
Definition of the critical ordinal ω₁^{ω+2}

overview.historicalContext: Erdős, Hajnal, and Milner (1970) established that P(α) holds for all α < ω₁^{ω+2}. Larson (1990) extended this to α < 2^{ℵ₀} under Martin's Axiom. The critical case α = ω₁^{ω+2} and the general conjecture remain open with prize money offered.
overview.problemStatement: For which limit ordinals α is it true that if G is a graph with vertex set α, then G must have either an infinite path or an independent set on a set of vertices with order type α?
overview.proofStrategy: We formalize ordinal graphs, infinite paths, independent sets with order types, the property P(α), Erdős-Hajnal-Milner theorem, the critical ordinal ω₁^{ω+2}, Martin's Axiom and Larson's result, ordinal arithmetic, graph-theoretic tools, and the general conjecture.
keyInsights: P(α) holds for α < 2^{ℵ₀} under Martin's Axiom (Larson 1990)
The critical case α = ω₁^{ω+2} is open ($250)
Connects graph theory with ordinal arithmetic and set theory

conclusion.summary: This formalization captures Erdős Problem #601 on the dichotomy between infinite paths and large independent sets in ordinal graphs. The property P(α) is known for α < ω₁^{ω+2}, with extensions under Martin's Axiom. The general case remains open with $500 prize.
conclusion.implications: The problem lies at the intersection of graph theory, set theory, and ordinal arithmetic. Resolution would illuminate the structure of infinite graphs and the role of set-theoretic axioms in combinatorics.
openQuestions: Does P(α) hold for all limit ordinals α? ($500)
Is the answer independent of ZFC?
